article.title: Spectroscopic survey of Kepler stars. II. FIES/NOT observations of A- and F-type stars

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: The difference between photometric and spectroscopic interstellar reddening as a function of effective temperature.
The difference between photometric and spectroscopic interstellar reddening as a function of surface gravity.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.
The distribution of projected rotational velocity for A and F type stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the right panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: The distribution of microturbulent velocity for A and F type stars.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
The difference between spectroscopic and photometric interstellar reddening for stars observed with HERMES and FIES.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and surface gravity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 1?
choices: Photometric interstellar reddening values from the KIC catalogue tend to be lower than the values derived from spectroscopic Na D2 line analysis.
Photometric interstellar reddening values from the KIC catalogue tend to be higher than the values derived from spectroscopic Na D2 line analysis.
There is no significant difference between photometric and spectroscopic interstellar reddening values.
The difference between photometric and spectroscopic interstellar reddening decreases with increasing effective temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 show?
choices: The distribution of projected rotational velocities for A and F type stars.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.
The comparison of effective temperatures derived using different methods: from spectral analysis, H2014 catalogue, SED fitting, and Balmer line analysis.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the effective temperatures derived from spectral analysis (Teff(Fe)) and those from the H2014 catalogue (Teff(H2014))?
choices: Teff(Fe) and Teff(H2014) are generally consistent within ±100 K.
Teff(Fe) tends to be higher than Teff(H2014), especially for chemically peculiar stars.
Teff(Fe) tends to be lower than Teff(H2014), especially for chemically peculiar stars.
There is a strong positive correlation between Teff(Fe) and Teff(H2014).

multiple_choice_question.text: Which method shows the best agreement with the effective temperatures derived from spectral analysis (Teff(Fe))?
choices: Effective temperatures derived from the H2014 catalogue (Teff(H2014)).
Effective temperatures derived from spectral energy distribution fitting (Teff(SED)).
Effective temperatures derived from Balmer line analysis (Teff(Balmer)).
All three methods show similar agreement with Teff(Fe).

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 show?
choices: The correlation between microturbulent velocity and surface gravity.
The distribution of projected rotational velocities for A and F type stars.
The comparison of surface gravities derived from spectral analysis (log g(Fe)) and those from the H2014 catalogue (log g(H2014)).
The comparison of effective temperatures derived using different methods.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the surface gravities derived from spectral analysis (log g(Fe)) and those from the H2014 catalogue (log g(H2014))?
choices: log g(Fe) and log g(H2014) are generally consistent within ±0.1 dex.
log g(Fe) tends to be higher than log g(H2014).
log g(Fe) tends to be lower than log g(H2014).
There is a strong positive correlation between log g(Fe) and log g(H2014).

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of data is more sensitive to surface gravity (log g)?
choices: Photometric data.
High-resolution spectra.
Both are equally sensitive.
None of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4 show?
choices: The distribution of microturbulent velocity for A and F type stars.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
The comparison of effective temperatures derived using different methods.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 4 about the relationship between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity?
choices: There is a strong positive correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
There is a strong negative correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
There is no significant correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
Microturbulence is determined with higher precision in rapidly rotating stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is microturbulence determined with higher precision in slow rotators?
choices: Slow rotators have simpler spectra with less line blending, allowing for the analysis of weak lines.
Slow rotators are intrinsically less turbulent.
Slow rotators are more common than fast rotators.
Slow rotators are easier to observe.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 show?
choices: The distribution of microturbulent velocity for A and F type stars.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
The comparison of effective temperatures derived using different methods.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in Figure 5 for the microturbulent velocity of A and F type stars?
choices: Microturbulent velocity increases linearly with increasing effective temperature.
Microturbulent velocity decreases linearly with increasing effective temperature.
Microturbulent velocity shows a broad maximum around 7000-8500 K.
There is no significant correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: How do the microturbulent velocities of Am stars compare to those of non-CP stars?
choices: Am stars have systematically higher microturbulent velocities than non-CP stars.
Am stars have systematically lower microturbulent velocities than non-CP stars.
The microturbulent velocities of Am stars are similar to those of non-CP stars.
There is no clear trend in the comparison of microturbulent velocities between Am stars and non-CP stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 show?
choices: The correlation between microturbulent velocity and projected rotational velocity.
The distribution of projected rotational velocities for all stars (panel a) and for all non-CP stars (panel b) analyzed in the paper.
The comparison of effective temperatures derived using different methods.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 6 about the typical projected rotational velocities of A and F type stars?
choices: Most A and F type stars are slow rotators with v sin i < 30 km/s.
Most A and F type stars have v sin i values greater than 120 km/s.
The distribution of v sin i is uniform across the sample.
There is no clear trend in the distribution of v sin i.

multiple_choice_question.text: What could be a possible explanation for the presence of non-CP A stars with low v sin i values?
choices: These stars are intrinsically slow rotators.
These stars are all members of binary systems.
These stars are fast rotators seen at a low inclination angle.
These stars are experiencing strong magnetic braking.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 7 show?
choices: The correlation between chemical abundances and effective temperature.
The distribution of projected rotational velocities for chemically peculiar stars.
The comparison of average abundances for non-CP, Am, and λ Boo stars with the solar abundances.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and iron abundance.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which group of elements shows the most significant differences in abundance compared to the solar values for Am stars?
choices: Light elements (C, N, O).
Iron-peak elements (Ca, Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni).
Heavy elements (Sr, Y, Zr, Ba, La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Dy, Er).
All element groups show similar deviations from solar abundances.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is a characteristic feature of λ Boo stars in terms of their chemical abundances?
choices: They show strong overabundances of iron-peak elements.
They show strong underabundances of iron-peak elements.
They have solar abundances of C, N, O and weak Mg II lines.
They have strong overabundances of heavy elements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 8 show?
choices: The distribution of projected rotational velocities for A and F type stars.
The correlation between microturbulent velocity and effective temperature.
The log Teff - log g diagram for the analyzed A and F type stars, with their variability classifications and evolutionary tracks.
The comparison of average abundances for non-CP, Am, and λ Boo stars with the solar abundances.

multiple_choice_question.text: Where are most of the Am stars located in the HR diagram?
choices: Inside the δ Sct instability strip.
Inside the γ Dor instability strip.
Outside both the δ Sct and γ Dor instability strips.
Randomly distributed across the diagram.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of variability is most common among the analyzed A and F type stars?
choices: δ Sct.
γ Dor.
Hybrid δ Sct/γ Dor.
Non-pulsating.
